On @realmoney May 31, 2019 | 12:57 PM EDT DOUG KASS Second and Third Level Thinking? First Level Thinking: Buy stocks now because of the reallocation trade (buy of stocks, sale of bonds) at day's (and month) end this afternoon - for a trade.

On @realmoney Down To Small In My Index Shorts I am moving to cover some more $SPY (at $275.44) and $QQQ (at $174.18) taking me down to small sized. My rationale is that today's Mexico tariff announcement was "newsy" (I like to counter punch in these cases) and though

I thought the S&P and Nasdaq would fall to today's levels (or lower) - the tariff tweet made it happen faster. I am hopeful I will have a chance to short strength in the days and weeks ahead - as I remain Bearish! @jimcramer @tomkeene @cnbcfastmoney @SquawkCNBC

On @realmoney Trading Around A Core Short I have covered a portion of my $SPY and $QQQ shorts at $275.90 and $174.49, respectively. As you all know I constantly trade around my Index positions (and even sometimes my core positions) when there are sharp short term moves (in either

direction). This is such a case - as these have been large "wins." Moreover, with a likely rebalancing at today's close (out of bonds and into stocks) it seems a prudent move. I am now only medium sized in my Index shorts. @jimcramer @tomkeene @cnbcfastmoney @SquawkCNBC

@realmoney @realdonaldtrump Recommended Listening Everyone should be required to listen to this Joe Rogan Experience podcast with Ed Calderon. (In its entirety! piped.video/watch?v=llhb2ymt…) * On Mexican cartels (abbreviated) piped.video/watch?v=MEjKdck2… * Cartels like the Trump border

(abbreviated) piped.video/watch?v=zc1WImJd… ; Ed Calderon is an ex border patrol agent (in Mexico) and now a securities specialist. I have lived in Mexico. The cartels own a lot of the country (and are growing larger in influence) and the government is notoriously corrupt.

Many politicians and even the police are afraid for their lives - its a serious crisis and getting worse. Most of the talking heads have no clue but pretend they do - and it appears neither does Navarro et al.

@realmoney May 31, 2019 | 12:36 PM EDT DOUG KASS Why It Is Different This Time The conditions that led to a market being able to recoup most of its late 2018 losses are no longer in place: * We are closer to an earnings recession than in 4Q2018. * At year end the domestic

economy was prepping for a +3% Real GDP in 1Q2019 - now Real GDP is expected to slide to below +1.5%. * The Cass Freight Index is showing profound weakness - and other high frequency economic data is weakening. * Markets have already priced in multiple interest rate cuts.

* With rates so low now (10 year yield down nearly 100 bps), there are few tools left in the monetary shed. * The prospects for any meaningful fiscal stimulation is gone (e.g., an infrastructure build) as the animus between the parties has intensified and will continue to erode

as we move to a November, 2020 election. * As mentioned in my opening missive, global coordination and cooperation is at an all-time low. * A relatively smooth and non disruptive BREXIT is no longer likely. * The trade backdrop is a mess - with disputes with Mexico and China (in

particular) probably going to continue for quite a while. * The geopolitical backdrop has deteriorated - particularly with Iran and North Korea. * Commodities are falling (especially of a crude-kind). * China's economic growth is no longer stable -
it's moving lower (see last night's manufacturing data). * Technicals have just begun to erode. @jimcramer @tomkeene
Never more - as in steep corrections - is Buffett's quote so obvious... "You never know who is swimming naked until the tide goes out."

@realmoney @realdonaldtrump and his sidekick Navarro should read this to understand how tariffs work. taxpolicycenter.org/taxvox/w… @saraeisen @jimcramer @tomkeene

From my opener on @realmoney Last night's news is consistent with my continuing concern regarding important issues of country coordination and cooperation I have been expressing in my Diary for more than two years.

As I have also written, simplistic policies ("prepared on the back of a napkin"), uninformed trade, tariff and other policies hastily crafted (and often conflated with politics) - with little sense of history - are dangerous in a world that is increasingly flat and networked.

(A good example is what I call "The Navarro Syndrome." Navarro, the Director of Trade and Industrial Policy, believes there is an inverse relationship between U.S. imports and U.S. GDP. Rather, history shows that there is a direct relationship between trade deficits and GDP.)

President Trump (and some of his advisors) have failed to recognize the past success of civil, deep and thoughtful negotiations and, instead, by upsetting the Post World War II order (and simplifying complicated issues), are failing to understand the multiplier impact of the

disruption of supply chains and other factors contained in an interconnected world. The decision to impose tariffs on Mexico is just another of a series of impulsive decisions by the Administration that have serious add-on effects. Its very bad policy.

Tariffs to deal with immigration? Only in the mind of President Trump is that a sensible approach. @jimcramer @tomkeene @arimelber @morningmoneyben @carlquintanilla @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney @morningmika @morning_joe @steverattner #msnbc @realdonaldtrump

Navarro is an economic imbecile. He doesnt understand the elementary economics of trade - which is frightening. @sareisen @jimcramer @tomkeene Read my opener on @realmoney "With Global Coordination at an All-Time Low, How Slow and Inept Will the
Reaction Be If the Wheels Do Come Off?" * The answer to the above question is... Slow, inept and impotent. @arimelber @morningmoneyben @morningmika @morning_joe @carlquintanilla
